author: By Shoshana Meira Friedman
title: Teaching My Child to Love a Dying World
description: My toddler son and I spoke about the trees as people — and indeed, for the first month of quarantine, they were the only people besides us he got to see up close.
content: This spring, as the world fell apart faster than we’d expected, I fell in love with trees. Not the crush of my girlhood when I admired them and fancied myself the child at the end of Dr. Seuss’s “The Lorax.” In love like I dreamed about them. I saw their bodies when I closed my eyes. Branches and trunks of different species traced my insides — the arch of the redbud’s trunk in joy and pleasure; the tight winter huddle of the spruce in fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Tyshawn Sorey: The Busiest Composer of the Bleakest Year
description: An artist straddling jazz and classical styles had perhaps the most exciting fall in new music.
content: “Everything Changes, Nothing Changes”: Tyshawn Sorey wrote the string quartet that bears that title in 2018. But the sentiment is so tailor-made for the past year that when the JACK Quartet announced it would stream a performance of the work in December, I briefly forgot and assumed it was a premiere, created for these tumultuous yet static times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristin Lin
title: ‘Because of You Guys, I’m Stuck in My Room’
description: Residents and caregivers at senior living facilities write about life during the pandemic — and trying to stay safe while facing the challenges of long-term isolation.
content: Devora Greenspon, 88, spent most of April, May and June confined to her room after residents at her long-term care facility in Toronto tested positive for the coronavirus. She couldn’t see her family and had very little human contact at all. A former special education teacher, she told me she found the isolation and loneliness of lockdown “so heartbreaking.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: 7 Ways to Socialize in a Frigid New York City
description: The best bet to see other people continues to be in the outdoors. But now the real test is here.
content: It’s officially winter. So what?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annalee Newitz
title: What New Science Techniques Tells Us About Ancient Women Warriors
description: Recent studies show that man was not always the hunter.
content: Though it’s remarkable that the United States finally is about to have a female vice president, let’s stop calling it an unprecedented achievement. As some recent archaeological studies suggest, women have been leaders, warriors and hunters for thousands of years. This new scholarship is challenging long-held beliefs about so-called natural gender roles in ancient history, inviting us to reconsider how we think about women’s work today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: New York to Delist Chinese Telecom Firms in Symbolic Shift
description: The move follows an order from the Trump administration, which says the companies are tied to China’s military. But they don’t need Wall Street as much as they once did.
content: The New York Stock Exchange said it would delist China’s three big state-run telecommunications companies following an executive order from the Trump administration, in a symbolic severing of longstanding ties between the Chinese business world and Wall Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Confessions of a Virtual Reality Gym Rat
description: The workouts are real, even if the impossibly beautiful scenery is not.
content: This year has created a lot of reluctant converts. Months ago, in less dire circumstances, we swore we’d never do any number of strange-sounding things: attend Zoom weddings, embrace ring lights, feed a sourdough starter. And yet here we are, making do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Black and Hispanic Americans turn to doctors who look like them for reassurance on vaccinations.
description: Denese Rankin, a 55-year-old retired bookkeeper and receptionist in Castleberry, Ala., did not want the Covid-19 vaccine. Her opinion toward the vaccine was like many Black, rural Americans: The vaccine had come about too quickly to be safe.
content: Denese Rankin, a 55-year-old retired bookkeeper and receptionist in Castleberry, Ala., did not want the Covid-19 vaccine. Her opinion toward the vaccine was like many Black, rural Americans: The vaccine had come about too quickly to be safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Overrides Trump’s Veto of Defense Bill, Dealing a Legislative Blow
description: Republicans joined Democrats to deliver President Trump the first veto override of his presidency in the last days of his term in an overwhelming, bipartisan vote.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Friday voted overwhelmingly to override President Trump’s veto of the annual military policy bill as most Republicans joined Democrats to rebuke Mr. Trump in the final days of his presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Shipstead
title: My Five-Week-Long First Date
description: Once I joined him on that ship for the Antarctic, there was no turning back.
content: “Wind twenty knots,” he wrote. “Thinking of you.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For New York, a Year of Pain and Reflection
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Jan. 1, 2021.
content: “We’ll all dance together as a family, and just have to go with the flow.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: A Top Equestrian Paralyzed in an Accident Sees Hope in a Coming Treatment
description: Kevin Babington was a go-to coach in the sport of show jumping, but an accident at a prime event left him paralyzed from the chest down and threatened his livelihood.
content: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. Here is our April report on Kevin Babington’s efforts to continue working in the equestrian world after a show-jumping accident left him paralyzed from the chest down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Gillian R. Brassil
title: What You Need to Know About Today’s College Football Playoff Semifinals
description: Alabama will play Notre Dame and Clemson will meet Ohio State on Friday as a chaotic season nears its end.
content: Four of the most fabled programs in college football — Alabama, Clemson, Ohio State and Notre Dame — still have hopes of winning the championship in one of the most chaotic, uncertain, week-to-week seasons in the sport’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fahima Haque
title: Jovan Adepo Pushes Through With Rachmaninoff and ‘Love Island’
description: The actor, starring in the latest adaptation of Stephen King’s “The Stand,” shared an eclectic list of what he is consuming to pass the time.
content: Jovan Adepo, known for his breakout turn in “Watchmen,” wasn’t familiar with “The Stand,” Stephen King’s dark fantasy novel about the survivors of an apocalyptic pandemic, before filming the TV adaptation that premiered as a mini-series in December on CBS All Access — and had no idea how close to home it would hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Jazmine Hughes
title: New York Halted Evictions. But What Happens When the Ban Ends?
description: A crisis looms in the pandemic’s wake: Evictions that threaten to overwhelm schools, homeless shelters and food pantries.
content: When New York State lawmakers approved emergency legislation this week to ban evictions for at least two months, they were seeking to prevent hundreds of thousands of people from being forced from their homes during the winter, with the pandemic still raging. But they also feared something more perilous: a broad ripping at the fabric of society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: How a Zen Buddhist Monk and Hospital Chaplain Spends His Sundays
description: To care for Covid-19 patients and their families, Seigan Ed Glassing reserves one day of the week to care for himself.
content: Even for someone accustomed to facing death, like Seigan Ed Glassing, who serves on the palliative care team at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, 2020 was a brutal year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Will 250 Lanterns Be Enough to Save Chinatown?
description: After a devastating year for small businesses, a new organization has a plan to bring life back to the neighborhood. First, hang some new lights.
content: Two days before Christmas, Mott Street, right in the heart of Chinatown, was filled with lights overnight. Residents woke up to 250 violet, pink, orange and gold lanterns hanging above the street. Local artists had painted whimsical designs and auspicious characters onto them: fu, for good fortune; he, for peace. Other characters stood for love, happiness, wealth and longevity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: For a Healthier 2021, Keep the Best Habits of a Very Bad Year
description: Our 7-Day Well Challenge will show you how to build on the healthy habits you learned during pandemic life.
content: Here’s a better way to start the new year: Skip the traditional January resolutions and make time for some New Year’s reflection instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Getting Married Where It All Began
description: Brandon Shih and Wenyi Gu met in their first college class, only to discover they lived in the same dorm. Almost a decade later, they eloped on the college campus where they fell in love.
content: On the first day of his first college class, Brandon Hsuan-Yuan Shih was nervously awaiting his turn to speak. He was in a freshman seminar at Princeton, and the students were asked to share something about themselves as an icebreaker. Mr. Shih had an answer prepared about how he loved music and playing tennis, until the woman sitting right next to him said the exact same thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Why Emptier Streets Meant an Especially Deadly Year for Traffic Deaths
description: In New York City, at least 243 people died in crashes in 2020 — the most since Mayor Bill de Blasio introduced his signature street safety plan in 2014.
content: When the pandemic hit New York City, cars seemed to disappear from many streets as the lockdown brought urban life to a halt and drivers stayed home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Make tinier New Year’s resolutions this year.
description: Go for small and achievable.
content: Welcome. A group of friends and I used to gather for brunch every year on New Year’s Day, and at the end of the meal, we’d each write a resolution on a slip of paper and put it in a hat. Then everyone drew from the hat, each receiving a random resolution, an assignment for the year from someone else at the table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Resolving to live a lot better than in 2020.
description: Every December since 2017, Ada Rojas has guided women through the process of memorializing their New Year’s resolutions on a vision board, a collage that reflects their goals and helps keep them on track. But this time around, Ms. Rojas is not holding the workshop Good Vibes & Chill until February.
content: Every December since 2017, Ada Rojas has guided women through the process of memorializing their New Year’s resolutions on a vision board, a collage that reflects their goals and helps keep them on track. But this time around, Ms. Rojas is not holding the workshop Good Vibes & Chill until February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Brexit Customs Checks Make a Quiet Debut at U.K. Ports
description: Starting the new rules on a holiday helped, with some predicting more confusion and backups in the days ahead.
content: LONDON — At the ports and terminals on Britain’s southeastern coast, a new era began on Friday morning without much fuss. Ferries and trains that carry goods to France from Dover and Folkestone were running on time, and drivers snaked their trucks into the port unencumbered by congestion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul, Richard Fausset and Michael LaForgia
title: Before Embracing America-First Agenda, David Perdue Was an Outsourcing Expert
description: Mr. Perdue, who faces one of two runoff elections in Georgia that will determine control of the Senate, built a business record that shifted manufacturing and jobs overseas.
content: The biographical video from Senator David Perdue’s first campaign, in 2014, celebrated a narrative arc that many fellow Georgians either related to or have aspired to: the story of a humble boy from rural America whose hard work catapulted him into a global business career, navigating free markets and faraway lands, all the while gathering stores of wisdom and wealth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: New Year’s Lawbreakers: 3 N.Y.C. Parties With Hundreds Are Broken Up
description: New Year’s Eve was mellow for most New Yorkers, and Times Square was practically empty. But some could not resist the lure of a big night out.
content: New York City, a place synonymous with the glitter and noise of New Year’s Eve, marked the close of a most unpredictable and upside-down of years in quiet deference to its dangers. In sending off a year so many would like to forget, New Yorkers spent a night that will instead be remembered, for its communal rejection of the usual fanfare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Chief Justice John Roberts commends the courts’ responses to the pandemic.
description: The nation’s courts have reacted nimbly to the coronavirus pandemic, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote in his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary.
content: The nation’s courts have reacted nimbly to the coronavirus pandemic, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote in his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Furnishing Your Home in a Pandemic Will Require Patience
description: The coronavirus has disrupted supply chains in unpredictable ways, creating long waits for basic items like dishwashers and love seats.
content: Shopping for a dishwasher isn’t what it used to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Virginia Judge Won’t Try Black Man in Courtroom Lined With White Portraits
description: David Bernhard, a circuit court judge, wrote in his decision that the display of portraits of white judges “is based on a non-racial principle, yet yields a racial result.”
content: When a Black man appears in a Virginia courtroom this month to stand trial on charges of eluding the police, assaulting an officer and other crimes, he will face a scene that defendants in that room have not experienced in decades: The portraits of white judges will no longer line the walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Is There a Future for Winnipeg’s Landmark Department Store?
description: The Hudson’s Bay Company’s now-closed downtown department store is surrounded by warm memories — and significant challenges in a post-pandemic world.
content: While it was already on death row, Hudson’s Bay Company’s presence in downtown Winnipeg ended with unexpected abruptness. After announcing that its much diminished former flagship outlet would be shut in February, the retailer permanently locked the doors of the 600,000-square-foot store at the end of November. Less than two weeks later, a crew arrived and stripped it of its signs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Ontario’s finance minister resigns after a jaunt in the Caribbean.
description: A senior minister in Ontario’s cabinet has resigned after vacationing in the Caribbean as residents of Canada’s most populous province were being urged to stay home.
content: A senior minister in Ontario’s cabinet has resigned after vacationing in the Caribbean as residents of Canada’s most populous province were being urged to stay home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: U.K. Eliminates Tax on Tampons and Other Sanitary Products
description: Britain is the latest of several countries to get rid of the tax in recent years.
content: Britain on Friday became the latest country to transform its measures on sanitary products by abolishing the so-called tampon tax, no longer classifying the products as nonessential and eliminating extra costs that many have criticized as sexist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: What to Know as Troubled Afghan Peace Talks Enter a New Phase
description: The Afghan government and the Taliban are set to continue negotiations toward a cease-fire in early January, but several fundamental issues stand in the way of progress.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — After four decades of grinding combat in Afghanistan, peace negotiations between the Afghan government and the Taliban have raised at least a possibility that the long cycle of violence might someday end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: Happy New Year
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Last night, mostly in muted celebrations, people around the world said goodbye to a difficult year and rang in 2021. We hope your night was meaningful and enjoyable in its own way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Gumbel
title: Britain Has Lost Itself
description: My grandparents, who fled Nazi Germany for Britain, would be heartbroken to see the country today.
content: At long last, it happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendon Derr, Rebecca Griesbach and Danya Issawi
title: States Are Shutting Down Prisons as Guards are Crippled By Covid-19
description: States and counties are finding it hard to keep jails and prisons open as the virus ravages both prisoners and staff members. But transferring inmates can spur new outbreaks.
content: Battered by a wave of coronavirus infections and deaths, local jails and state prison systems around the United States have resorted to a drastic strategy to keep the virus at bay: Shutting down completely and transferring their inmates elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Miller
title: Swimming in Very Cold Water Keeps Me Sane
description: Maybe at another time in human history I would have cared about the health benefits, but at this point, I’m like, what does “good for you” even mean?
content: I’m standing with two friends in the 39-degree air on the edge of a lake in northeastern California in just our bathing suits. A lone fisherman in several layers of outerwear stares, drinks from a bottle of Racer Ale and says, “Tell me you ladies aren’t going in that water.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Infrared Drones, Search Parties and a Lasso: Chasing a Runaway Llama
description: In a season of uncommon grief and worry, people far beyond the Westchester County estate from which Gizmo escaped were all too happy to fret about something else, for a change.
content: BEDFORD CORNERS, N.Y. — Diana Heimann is the kind of person who traps mice in her farmhouse and releases them into nature preserves. The kind of person who kept Silkie chickens in her living room and their eggs in the cup holders of her car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Without Trump, or Masks, Mar-a-Lago Partied On
description: President Trump did not attend his private social club’s annual New Year’s Eve bash, which hundreds of guests attended despite the coronavirus.
content: President Trump’s private social club in Palm Beach, Fla., hosted a New Year’s Eve gala at which revelers without masks dined indoors and danced to performances by Vanilla Ice and members of the Beach Boys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Party Hearty
description: Milo Beckman hides some pleasant surprises in his New Year’s puzzle — let’s hope for more of that!
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I hope people have a lot of fun with this “themeless” Friday, which revealed its center (to this solver, at least) like a secret box with a series of sliding parts. If Milo Beckman's name isn’t quite unexpected, that’s because he’s constructed for The Times before, mainly in the early 2010s. Hopefully this lively grid marks his return to the regular rotation and we see more of him in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Premier League Has a Schedule. It Really Needs a Plan.
description: As the coronavirus invades locker rooms and postpones matches, soccer needs to face up to a potential worst-case scenario.
content: On the face of it, the Premier League’s decision was an easy and an obvious one. Manchester City and Manchester United had finished last season late, thanks to their commitments in the summer’s European competitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Asks Judge to Toss Election Lawsuit Against Pence
description: The suit, led by Representative Louie Gohmert of Texas, seeks to give the vice president the power to reject electoral votes that were cast for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: The Justice Department asked a federal judge on Thursday to reject a lawsuit seeking to pressure Vice President Mike Pence to overturn the results of the election, pitting the department against President Trump’s allies in Congress who have refused to accept President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Can You Poison Your Way to Good Health?
description: West Coast wellness elites think kambo, an Amazonian frog poison drug, is helping them purge “toxins” from their lives.
content: “It’s like you’re having a fever or a major allergic reaction,” said Julia Allison, 39, now a media strategist for tech companies in San Francisco, recalling her first time taking kambo, a poisonous substance from an Amazonian frog that is trending as an alt-wellness wonder drug. “Then your face starts to blow up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: France couldn’t stop the New Year’s parties. One rave drew 2,500 people who fought off the police.
description: Local authorities said that stones and bottles were thrown at police officers who tried to break up the party, and that a police car was set on fire.
content: Faced with a resurgence of Covid-19 infections, French authorities pulled out all the stops to ensure that France would step into 2021 in safety. An existing nationwide overnight curfew was enforced on New Years’s Eve by some 130,000 police officers; all public celebrations were banned and the government advised to limit private gatherings to six people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: How Trump Tried, but Largely Failed, to Derail America’s Top Climate Report
description: The White House repeatedly attempted to thwart the country’s premier climate science document, one meant to steer policy for years. Scientists got in the way.
content: The National Climate Assessment, America’s premier contribution to climate knowledge, stands out for many reasons: Hundreds of scientists across the federal government and academia join forces to compile the best insights available on climate change. The results, released just twice a decade or so, shape years of government decisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Mapo tofu, Sicilian-style citrus salad, black bean soup: Start the year off with great eating.
content: Good morning. You aren’t, I hope, struggling this morning after a night of excess, considering your options at the crossroads of madness and death. If 2020 gave us anything it was an excuse — an order, really — not to gather on New Year’s Eve for its sad, sentimental dance of forced cheer and sweet Champagne, its endless hours before that dreadful song. Here we are in a new year, still very much like the last one, though there’s light now at the end of the tunnel and we dare to be hopeful sometimes, particularly today. We feel good, despite all!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Egan
title: After Five Centuries, a Native American With Real Power
description: The expected nomination of Deb Haaland.
content: In the American West, a ration of reverence is usually given to the grizzled Anglo rancher who rises at a public hearing and announces that his people have been on the land for five generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Smith
title: Upcoming N.H.L. Season Will Have Flashes of Other Difficult Eras
description: All of the Canadian teams will be in the same division, as they were in the late 1920s and most of the 1930s. And as during World War II, external circumstances will affect roster sizes.
content: The first time a pandemic halted a professional hockey season was in 1919, when an outbreak of the Spanish flu ended the Stanley Cup finals before a champion could be crowned. Just days after the cancellation, Montreal Canadiens defenseman Joe Hall, who had played in the finals, died in a Seattle hospital of pneumonia related to the flu. He was 37.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi and Ernesto Londoño
title: How Support for Legal Abortion Went Mainstream in Argentina
description: The fight for legalization began decades ago, but it gained traction only as more women became lawmakers and a massive grass-roots effort shifted the conversation.
content: BUENOS AIRES — It was just two years ago that the organizers of a stirring women’s movement in Argentina were handed what felt like a bitter loss, their efforts to legalize abortion rejected in the Senate after intense lobbying by the Catholic Church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: How the Oldest Old Can Endure Even This
description: No visitors. No friends at the dining table. Neighbors dying without notice. But many older adults have proved resilient during the pandemic, a phenomenon known as “crisis competence.”
content: It was sometime in the spring that Ruth Willig, then 96, first compared her pandemic life to being in prison. My mother, Dorothy, was still alive then, in a building much like the assisted-living facility in Brooklyn where Ruth lives. The buildings had shut down all visitors and stopped all group activities, including meals in the dining room. Residents spent their days in their apartments, alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: Shhh! In Los Angeles, New Year’s Eve parties are still happening.
description: Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, well-attended parties have mostly been shut down across Los Angeles, which has led to a culture of secrecy on social media.
content: Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, well-attended parties have mostly been shut down across Los Angeles, which has led to a culture of secrecy on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Armando Manzanero, Influential Mexican Balladeer, Is Dead
description: He was known as one of the great romantic composers. His songs were performed by Elvis Presley, Andrea Bocelli, Christina Aguilera and many others.
content: Armando Manzanero, one of Mexico’s greatest romantic composers, whose ballads were performed by the likes of Elvis Presley and Christina Aguilera, died on Monday in Mexico City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Top Sales Show How Pandemic Continues to Influence the Market
description: Single-family houses and penthouses remained in demand in December as buyers sought out homes with more personal space.
content: Several more Manhattan townhouse sales closed in December, many at holiday-style discounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Minneapolis Police Release Body Camera Video of Its First Killing Since George Floyd
description: The video shows a man raising something to his car window before a bang is heard. An officer ducks for cover and then fires several rounds at the man.
content: The Minneapolis Police Department released body camera footage on Thursday that shed new light on a fatal police shooting the night before, the first killing by a city police officer since George Floyd’s death in the spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gilbert Cruz
title: Love Music to Surprise You? Jon Caramanica Recommends TikTok Dives
description: The Times’s Culture editor has questions. Our critic has answers.
content: As the editor of the Culture department at The New York Times, Gilbert Cruz relies on critics, reporters and editors in every field of the arts for their expertise. Now we’re bringing his personal questions — and our writers’ answers — to you. Currently on his mind: how to open himself up to new music, and tangle with the beast known as TikTok, which he posed to Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fareed Zakaria on Life After the Pandemic
description: Zakaria discusses “Ten Lessons for a Post-Pandemic World,” and Margaret MacMillan talks about “War: How Conflict Shaped Us.”
content: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Echikson
title: The celebration at Mar-a-Lago doesn’t include President Trump.
description: The town of Palm Beach, Fla.,  imposed a 1 a.m. curfew, limiting New Year’s Eve festivities.
content: The glittering, black-tie New Year’s Eve celebration at the president’s Mar-a-Lago resort had in previous years been one of the highlights of the social season in Palm Beach, Fla. People paid hundreds of dollars for tickets. Celebrities including Sylvester Stallone, Rod Stewart and Woody Allen attended. Guests feasted on caviar and drank Champagne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Meals for a New Year
description: Start the new year with a lovable combination: chicken soup with rice.
content: We made it! Happy New Year, and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. I’m hopeful we’ll have a year that is better than the last, though 2020 was not entirely without small pops of good news. (If you haven’t heard it yet, there is a wonderful episode of “The Daily” devoted to this subject.) For me, it was the arrival of my second child, whose first word (besides Mama), uttered in December, was “Hi!” It feels particularly sunny and gregarious after a year that was so dark and insular. We hear her yelling it all over the house. HI!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Ellin
title: A Ceremony Led by Richard Branson
description: Sayé Yabandeh and Dr. Jeffrey Neal were instantly drawn to each other at a snow polo event in Aspen, Colo.
content: For the last five Decembers, Sayé Yabandeh has participated in the St. Regis World Snow Polo Championship, a charity event in Aspen, Colo. It’s a magical affair held in a magical location, and exactly the sort of place you want to share with someone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Britain Opts for Mix-and-Match Vaccinations, Confounding Experts
description: If a second dose of one vaccine isn’t available, another may be substituted, according to new U.K. guidelines.
content: Amid a sputtering vaccine rollout and fears of a new and potentially more transmissible variant of the coronavirus, Britain has quietly updated its vaccination playbook to allow for a mix-and-match vaccine regimen. If a second dose of the vaccine a patient originally received isn’t available, or if the manufacturer of the first shot isn’t known, another vaccine may be substituted, health officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: No Rose Parade: Southern California laments the loss of a tradition.
description: The pandemic caused the cancellation of the Rose Parade, an institution since 1890, for the first time since World War II.
content: For just about every New Year’s Day since 1958, Carla Hall has situated herself on a patch of asphalt in front of a car dealership in downtown Pasadena, Calif. To a 10-year-old girl, it was the perfect spot to watch the majesty unfold — the “artistry” she calls it, of the floats and the marching bands, the beauty queens and horses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: David Fincher, the Unhappiest Auteur
description: The director makes beautiful bummers in an industry that prefers happy endings. Perhaps that’s why his movies seem like an endangered species.
content: For nearly three decades, David Fincher has been making gorgeous bummer movies that — in defiance of Hollywood’s first principle — insist that happy endings are a lie. Filled with virtuosic images of terrible deeds and violence, his movies entertain almost begrudgingly. Even when good somewhat triumphs, the victories come at a brutal cost. No one, Fincher warns, is going to save us. You will hurt and you will die, and sometimes your pretty wife’s severed head will end up in a box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Things Will Get Better. Seriously.
description: Reasons to be hopeful about the Biden economy.
content: The next few months will be hell in terms of politics, epidemiology and economics. But at some point in 2021 things will start getting better. And there’s good reason to believe that once the good news starts, the improvement in our condition will be much faster and continue much longer than many people expect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin and Weiyi Cai
title: Why Markets Boomed in a Year of Human Misery
description: It wasn’t just the Fed or the stimulus. The rise in savings among white-collar workers created a tide lifting nearly all financial assets.
content: The central, befuddling economic reality of the United States at the close of 2020 is that everything is terrible in the world, while everything is wonderful in the financial markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Pandemic Driving Is Still Down, but Will Insurers Grant More Relief?
description: Many gave drivers a break in the spring. With accident claims remaining below normal, consumer advocates are calling for another one.
content: When Americans abruptly cut back on driving early in the pandemic, many auto insurance companies gave customers credits or refunds on their premiums, reflecting the lower risk of accidents with fewer cars on the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas St. Fleur
title: Meteor Showers in 2021 That Will Light Up Night Skies
description: All year long, Earth passes through streams of cosmic debris. Here’s a list of some major meteor showers and how to spot them.
content: All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Dr. Fauci advises against the British approach of delaying a second dose of vaccine.
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, told CNN on Friday that the United States would not follow Britain’s lead in front-loading first vaccine injections, potentially delaying the administration of second doses.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, told CNN on Friday that the United States would not follow Britain’s lead in front-loading first vaccine injections, potentially delaying the administration of second doses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Nark
title: The Problem With Problem Sharks
description: A marine biologist’s ideas for singling out sharks that attack humans have prompted objections from other shark scientists.
content: The war on sharks has been waged with shock and awe at times. When a shark bit or killed a swimmer, people within the past century might take out hundreds of the marine predators to quell the panic, like executing everyone in a police lineup in order to ensure justice was dispensed on the guilty party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Joan Micklin Silver, Director of ‘Crossing Delancey,’ Dies at 85
description: She broke barriers for women, directing seven feature films, including “Hester Street” and “Between the Lines,” as well as TV movies.
content: Joan Micklin Silver, the filmmaker whose first feature, “Hester Street,” expanded the marketplace for American independent film and broke barriers for women in directing, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: An Imprint Neither Could Forget
description: Matthew Specktor and Samantha Culp first met at a book-signing benefit in 2013. They reconnected nearly six years later on a dating website.
content: Long before the name Matthew Specktor was inscribed on Samantha Culp’s heart, it could be found beneath a short, sweet note inscribed on a page of Mr. Specktor’s book, “American Dream Machine,” which she bought at a benefit at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles in June 2013.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: In Pasadena, Moving the Rose Bowl Makes For Unusual Rancor
description: The Rose Bowl moved to Texas from California to accommodate fans. But in Pasadena, city officials worried the maneuver could threaten its long-held ties to the game.
content: Many people know of genteel Pasadena, Calif., if only from New Year’s Day television, waking up to the palm-tree-lined Rose Parade down Colorado Boulevard, or stirring from a football-watching stupor long enough to admire the Technicolor sunset splashed on the San Gabriel Mountains behind the Rose Bowl stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Congress Poised to Apply Banking Regulations to Antiquities Market
description: Regulators have long worried that the secrecy of the antiquities trade, where buyers and sellers are seldom identified, made it an easy way to launder money.
content: The antiquities trade, which regulators have long feared provided fertile ground for money laundering and other illicit activities, will be subject to greater oversight under legislation passed by Congress on Friday when it overrode President Trump’s veto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Florida health officials detect the state’s first identified coronavirus variant case.
description: A highly contagious coronavirus variant first identified in Britain has been discovered in Florida, health officials said on Thursday.
content: A highly contagious coronavirus variant first identified in Britain has been discovered in Florida, health officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: John Outterbridge, Who Turned Castoffs Into Sculpture, Dies at 87
description: Leftover wood, rags, rusted metal — all were his materials, and pieced together as assemblages, they told stories about history, about culture and about him.
content: LOS ANGELES — John Outterbridge, a Los Angeles cultural leader and artist who made powerful sculptures from what is usually dismissed as junk or castoffs — a means of exploring loaded social issues as well as celebrating a history of African-American resourcefulness — died here on Nov. 12. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins, Frances Robles and Tim Arango
title: The U.S. enters 2021 playing catch-up with its vaccine distribution, prompting sharp words from Mitt Romney.
description: The Utah senator called it “as incomprehensible as it is inexcusable” that “comprehensive vaccination plans have not been developed at the federal level and sent to the states as models.”
content: The United States begins the new year far behind schedule in its coronavirus vaccine rollout, having distributed shots to a mere fraction of the 20 million it had hoped to reach by this time, even as the nation hit a grim new milestone on New Year’s Eve: 20 million cases since the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: The U.S. reaches 20 million cases.
description: The United States recorded its 20 millionth case since the start of the coronavirus pandemic on Thursday, surpassing a grim milestone just as the prospects for getting the virus under control quickly in the new year appeared to dim.
content: The United States recorded its 20 millionth case since the start of the coronavirus pandemic on Thursday, surpassing a grim milestone just as the prospects for getting the virus under control quickly in the new year appeared to dim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: How Israel Became a World Leader in Vaccinating Against Covid-19
description: Badly hit by the coronavirus, Israel has distributed the first of two vaccine doses to more than 10 percent of its population. Prime Minister Netanyahu is leading the charge, bolstering his own battered image along the way.
content: JERUSALEM — More than 10 percent of Israel’s population has received a first dose of a coronavirus vaccine, a rate that has far outstripped the rest of the world and buoyed the battered domestic image of the country’s leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, at a critical juncture.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How 2020 Changed Our Minds
description: Listeners join the hosts to weigh in on the many ways this hellish year made them think differently.
content: Listen and subscribe to “The Argument” from your mobile device:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Dobbins
title: In a Widening News Desert on the Border, a Tabloid Start-Up Defies the Odds
description: People in Del Rio, Texas, complain that nothing ever happens there. Those are fighting words for the publisher of The 830 Times, though he admits that keeping his paper afloat might be the biggest news of all.
content: DEL RIO, Texas — At the Chihuahuan Desert’s eastern limits, in a parking lot above Lake Amistad, Brian Argabright photographed anglers and their catch at the Border Bass Battle for The Del Rio News-Herald, a chronicler of the wind-swept border town since 1884.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Coming Home
description: Tens of thousands of New Yorkers left the city when the pandemic struck and spent months living elsewhere. What did they learn?
content: They fled east to Long Island, west to New Jersey and Pennsylvania, north across New England and south to Florida, seeking freedom of movement and safe shelter anywhere the virus wasn’t yet raging like an out-of-control fire. Between March 1 and May 1, as the first wave of the Covid-19 pandemic hit New York, about 5 percent of the population, or 420,000 New Yorkers, left the city, according to cellphone data analyzed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A very different New Year’s Eve.
content: Most places in the world, from a virtually coronavirus-free New Zealand to an Ireland in lockdown, have now greeted the arrival of 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Soft Spot for Yalies
description: Prof. Liz Schneider put a personal ad in the Yale Alumni Magazine. Dr. Ben Liptzin answered it six months later.
content: Elizabeth M. Schneider always had a soft spot for Yalies — her father and son went there — and she could belt out Bulldog football team fight songs and the “Bright College Years” unofficial alma mater with the best of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Virus Numbers Are Surging. Why Is New York’s Vaccine Rollout Sluggish?
description: With a new variant of the virus emerging elsewhere in the country, it’s crucial to vaccinate New Yorkers quickly. But so far, only about 88,000 have received the shots.
content: As the final hours ticked away in a harrowing year, New York City on Thursday once again found itself in a worrying position in the pandemic: Hospitalizations were climbing for the fourth consecutive month, the positive test rate in some areas had doubled and vaccinations that were supposed to bring normalcy had gotten off to a slow start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Elizabeth Is Missing’ Review: Glenda Jackson’s Return to TV
description: The renowned actress stars as a woman fending off dementia while she searches for a lost friend.
content: The BBC television movie “Elizabeth Is Missing” — a stand-alone episode of “Masterpiece” on PBS this Sunday — contains Glenda Jackson’s first screen performance since 1992. That certainly merits attention — Jackson, now 84, is one of the most technically accomplished and ferociously intelligent actresses of our time. Did it merit the rapturous British reviews on its release in 2019 and perhaps inevitable awards, including a BAFTA and an international Emmy, that she received for it? Not really, but it isn’t Jackson’s fault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: In Abrupt Reversal of Iran Strategy, Pentagon Orders Aircraft Carrier Home
description: After weeks of escalation and threatening language, the Defense Department is sending mixed messages as the anniversary of the death of an Iranian general nears.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has abruptly sent the aircraft carrier Nimitz home from the Middle East and Africa over the objections of top military advisers, marking a reversal of a weekslong muscle-flexing strategy aimed at deterring Iran from attacking American troops and diplomats in the Persian Gulf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: A Monster Wind Turbine Is Upending an Industry
description: G.E.’s giant machine, which can light up a small town, is stoking a renewable-energy arms race.
content: Twirling above a strip of land at the mouth of Rotterdam’s harbor is a wind turbine so large it is difficult to photograph. The turning diameter of its rotor is longer than two American football fields end to end. Later models will be taller than any building on the mainland of Western Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: An Embattled Public Servant in a Fractured France
description: Nicolas Cadène sees the failings of France’s secular model even as he upholds it.
content: PARIS — France is in theory a nondiscriminatory society where the state upholds strict religious neutrality and people are free to believe, or not, in any God they wish. It is a nation, in its self image, that through education dissolves differences of faith and ethnicity in a shared commitment to the rights and responsibilities of French citizenship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Toby Bilanow
title: Weekly Health Quiz: A New Coronavirus Variant, Diet Guidelines and Really Short Workouts
description: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: The Weekender
description: Discover readers’ positive moments of 2020. Also in this edition: the inspiring resilience of a marathoner, the bizarre story of a runaway llama and more.
content: Discover readers’ positive moments of 2020. Also in this edition: the inspiring resilience of a marathoner, the bizarre story of a runaway llama and more.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Choosing to Be Displaced
description: More than 400,000 New Yorkers left the city at the beginning of the pandemic. Many have returned; all have re-evaluated their relationship with the city.
content: More than 400,000 New Yorkers left the city at the beginning of the pandemic. Many have returned; all have re-evaluated their relationship with the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Senate Votes to Override Trump’s Veto of Defense Bill
description: Republicans joined Democrats on Friday to override President Trump’s veto of the annual defense bill, delivering him the first such legislative rebuke of his presidency.
content: Republicans joined Democrats on Friday to override President Trump’s veto of the annual defense bill, delivering him the first such legislative rebuke of his presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 1, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Jan. 1, 2021.
content: A headline with an article on Thursday about cases of a more contagious form of the coronavirus in Colorado and California referred incorrectly to the virus. The new cases show a new variant of the virus, not a new strain.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Horrified by the Blackwater Pardons
description: The F.B.I. agent who led the Blackwater investigation and two other letter writers are appalled by the pardon of men who killed innocent civilians.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Will Pence Do When Congress Counts the Votes?
description: Readers are shocked that the question is being asked and speculate that the vice president may find an excuse not to be present. They also criticize Senator Josh Hawley.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
